title: 110_hr4926
content: The Act may be cited as the "Josh Miller Helping Everyone Access Responsive Treatment in Schools Act of 2008" or the "Josh Miller HEARTS Act." It establishes a grant program for automated external defibrillators. The Secretary of Education will provide grants to local educational agencies for purchasing automated external defibrillators or providing training for schools to meet requirements. Agencies must apply to be eligible for the grants. To be eligible for a grant to receive an automated external defibrillator, schools must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. Local educational agencies must provide matching funds equal to 25% of the grant amount from non-Federal sources, unless waived by the Secretary. Internet- or computer-based community schools are not eligible for the grant. Local educational agencies must demonstrate that schools with automated external defibrillators have at least 5 trained individuals aged 18 or older who are employees or volunteers. In order to receive grants, schools must maintain certification in using automated external defibrillators and CPR from recognized organizations. Paramedics must be informed of defibrillator locations on school grounds, and the devices must be integrated into emergency response plans. Priority for grants is given to schools without defibrillators on site. The section discusses the criteria for schools to receive grants for defibrillators on school grounds, emphasizing the importance of quick access to emergency medical services. The terms used in the section are defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 through 2013 to carry out this section.
